chapter.title: 57 Bacteroides, Porphyromonas, Prevotella, Fusobacterium, and Other Anaerobic Gram-Negative Rods

sect1.title: 57 Bacteroides, Porphyromonas, Prevotella, Fusobacterium, and Other Anaerobic Gram-Negative Rods

para.phrase: GEORG CONRADS, ELISABETH NAGY, AND EIJA KÖNÖNEN

sect2.title: TAXONOMY AND DESCRIPTION OF THE GROUP
sect2.para: Most of the obligately anaerobic, Gram-negative, non-spore-forming rods of clinical relevance belong to the phylumBacteroidetes, order Bacteroidales, including families Bacteroidaceae, Porphyromonadaceae, Prevotellaceae, and Rikenellaceae, and to the phylum Fusobacteria, order Fusobacteriales, including the families Fusobacteriaceae and Leptotrichiaceae. In addition, clinically important taxa representing anaerobic, Gram-negative, non-spore-forming rods exist in some other phyla, such as Firmicutes, Proteobacteria, and Synergistetes. There have been a considerable number of changes in the taxonomy of the taxa that are covered in this chapter; two new genera have been named, and several novel species have been described in the past few years. The changes made since 2017 are restricted to validly published new taxa, which are listed in Table 1. Table 2 gives characteristics of anaerobic Gram-negative genera that have grown from clinical specimens, and these are summarized below.

Within the familyBacteroidaceae, the genus Bacteroides consists of saccharolytic, bile-resistant, and nonpigmented species, mainly isolated from the gut. The genus is limited to species within the Bacteroides fragilis group (1). It includes 101 validly published species, of which more than half have been recovered from humans (for an update see www.bacterio.net). Of these, especially B. fragilis, B. thetaiotaomicron, and B. ovatus are most relevant in human infections (2). Five new species, B. faecalis, B. koreensis, B. kribbi, B. luhongzhouii, and B. zhangwenhongii, were recently isolated from human fecal samples (Table 1) (3–5).

The genusAlistipes, which belongs to the family Rikenellaceae, currently includes 10 validly published species: A. communis (new), A. dispar (new), A. finegoldii, A. indistinctus, A. ihumii (validated), A. inops, A. onderdonkii (now divided into two subspecies), A. putredinis, A. shahii, and A. timonensis (6–8). In general, Alistipes species are straight or slightly curved short rods. Pigmentation, catalase reaction, indole production, and resistance to bile are variable.

The familyPorphyromonadaceae includes seven genera with species detected in humans: Barnesiella, Butyricimonas, Coprobacter, Odoribacter, Parabacteroides, Porphyromonas, and Tannerella. Of these genera, Porphyromonas is clinically most relevant. There are currently 20 validly published Porphyromonas species, many of which are of animal origin. P. asaccharolytica, P. bennonis, P. catoniae, P. endodontalis, P. gingivalis, P. somerae, and P. uenonis are frequently detected in humans (9–13). More recently described species of human origin are P. bronchialis (a validly published synonym of P. macacae), isolated from intraoperative bronchial fluids of an elderly patient with non-small cell lung cancer (14); P. pasteri, isolated from human saliva (15); and P. pogonae, isolated from lizards, but also from human specimens taken from acute sinusitis, soft tissue infection, and blood (16–18). Most species are asaccharolytic and pigmented; however, a growing number of species, including P. bennonis, P. catoniae, P. pasteri, P. pogonae, and P. bronchialis, are nonpigmented. Human Parabacteroides species consist of P. distasonis, P. faecis, P. goldsteinii, P. gordonii, P. johnsonii, and P. merdae, as well as two novel species, P. acidifaciens from human feces (19) and P. chongii, isolated from blood of a patient with periodontitis (20). Parabacteroides organisms are saccharolytic and resistant to 20% bile. The genus is phylogenetically closely related to the genera Tannerella and Barnesiella, both being anaerobic, nonpigmented, nonmotile, pleomorphic rods. The genus Tannerella currently contains two species, T. forsythia (formerly T. forsythensis) (21), which is an important oral pathogen, and the newly described T. serpentiformis, with a snake-like morphology (22). The genus Barnesiella still has only one human species, B. intestinihominis, isolated from feces (23). The genus Butyricimonas contains the novel species B. faecalis (24), B. faecihominis, and B. paravirosa of human fecal origin. B. virosa, originally isolated from rat feces, has been isolated from several cases of bacteremia in humans (25, 26). The genus Coprobacter, with C. fastidiosus, a nonmotile Gram-negative rod isolated from infant feces, and the second discovered species C. secundus, isolated from stool (27), is most closely related to Barnesiella (28) and has no reported clinical significance to date. The genus Odoribacter includes two human-derived species, O. splanchnicus (formerly Bacteroides) and O. laneus (29, 30). O. splanchnicus is saccharolytic and bile resistant, while O. laneus is asaccharolytic and susceptible to 20% bile.

The familyPrevotellaceae includes saccharolytic or moderately saccharolytic short rods that produce acetic and succinic acids as their major end products of fermentation (31). This family has increased by the addition of a tremendous number of novel species and species candidates in recent years. Most novel Prevotella species have been isolated from the oral cavity (32–36) but also from feces (37) and from other sites of the body, where they have been associated with various clinical conditions (38–43). Six validly published Prevotella species of human origin, P. brunnea, P. hominis, P. lascolaii, P. phocaeensis, P. rara, and P. vespertina, were described recently (44–49). P. heparinolytica and P. zoogleoformans, mainly isolated from infected cat and dog bite wounds, are only loosely connected to other Prevotella species and, instead, cluster phylogenetically with Bacteroides species. Alloprevotella, a genus phylogenetically close to Prevotella, contains the former Prevotella tannerae, reassigned to A. tannerae, and A. rava (50). Another genus distantly related to Prevotella, Paraprevotella, consists of P. clara and P. xylaniphila, isolated from human feces (51).

The phylumBacteroidetes includes a genus Phocaeicola, with 12 validly published species. Two recent milestone publications validated most of the species described (52, 53) and quite a few are of human fecal origin. However, except for P. abscessus (54), P. dorei (55) (with most information available under the former name Bacteroides dorei), and P. (formerly Bacteroides) massiliensis (56), no clinical implications in humans have been described.

In the familyFusobacteriaceae of the phylum Fusobacteria, the genera of clinical interest are Fusobacterium, Leptotrichia, and Sneathia. These organisms are nonmotile, pleomorphic rods, mainly isolated from the oral cavity and female genital tract. The somewhat fuzzy phylogeny of fusobacteria and great heterogeneity of F. nucleatum, in particular, have been explained by potential horizontal gene transfer that occurred in the close interaction of oral bacteria within dental biofilms (57, 58). The fusobacterial subspecies show sex-specific differences in abundance and are implicated in carcinogenesis (59, 60). The genus Leptotrichia consists of nonmotile, highly saccharolytic, long rods that typically produce lactic acid. The current validly described Leptotrichia species are L. buccalis, L. hofstadii, L. hongkongensis, L. shahii, L. trevisanii, and L. wadei, while L. goodfellowii has been reclassified as Pseudoleptotrichia (new genus) goodfellowii (61). “L. amnionii,” originally isolated from amniotic fluid (62), was recently validly reclassified as Sneathia vaginalis (63), also replacing S. amnii (64).

Among the phylumSynergistetes, there are few cultivable human species, namely Fretibacterium fastidiosum (65), Jonquetella anthropi (66), Pyramidobacter piscolens (67), and Rarimicrobium hominis (68, 69). In addition, two Cloacibacillus species, C. evryensis and C. porcorum, originating from an anaerobic sludge digestor and from a pig cecum, respectively, have been isolated from human specimens (69). They are obligately anaerobic, nonmotile, Gram-negative organisms. Fluorescence in situ hybridization analysis has revealed that the oral cavity harbors further unculturable Synergistetes, which are large curved bacilli (70), and they are widely distributed in various human ecosystems in both health and disease (70, 71).

In the Gram-positive phylumFirmicutes, the class Negativicutes harbors organisms with a traditional Gram-negative cell wall structure (72), including some clinically important genera such as Dialister, Megamonas, Selenomonas, and Centipeda. The genus Dialister includes six species of human origin: D. invisus (73) and D. pneumosintes (formerly Bacteroides pneumosintes) isolated from the oral cavity, D. micraerophilus and D. propionicifaciens (74) from clinical specimens, as well as D. succinatiphilus and the recently described D. hominis from feces (23, 75). These anaerobic or microaerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli are asaccharolytic and largely unreactive in biochemical tests (74). The two human species of the genus Megamonas, M. hypermegale and M. funiformis (76), are anaerobic, Gram-negative, very large rods. In the genus Selenomonas, S. artemidis, S. dianae, S. flueggei, S. infelix, S. noxia, and S. sputigena, and also the closely related Centipeda periodontii, have been isolated from the human oral cavity (77). They are anaerobic, space Gram-negative curved motile rods. Two strictly anaerobic, Gram-negative, nonmotile, long rod-shaped strains from human feces have been characterized and classified as Phascolarctobacterium succinatutens in the family Acidaminococcaceae (78). Christensenella minuta and Christensenella intestinihominis, from human feces or mixed anaerobic infections, are anaerobic short rods with a Gram-negative cell wall (79–81). Phylogenetically, they belong to a novel family, Christensenellaceae, within the phylum Firmicutes.

Various families in the phylumProteobacteria include some anaerobic genera and species with clinical importance in humans. The genera Sutterella, Mesosutterella (new genus), and Parasutterella are among the family Sutterellaceae (82). They consist of asaccharolytic, bile-resistant, Gram-negative short rods or coccobacilli, of which S. wadsworthensis, S. parvirubra, S. megalosphaeroides (new species [83]), P. excrementihominis, P. secunda, and M. multiformis (new species [83]) have been isolated from human specimens. The family Desulfovibrionaceae contains two genera of clinical interest, Bilophila and Desulfovibrio. Bilophila wadsworthia is an anaerobic, asaccharolytic, bile-resistant, Gram-negative rod and is a significant pathogen in humans (84). Of the more than 70 Desulfovibrio species and subspecies, only a few infrequently cause a variety of human infections (85). In the family Desulfomicrobiaceae, the genus Desulfomicrobium includes one human species, D. orale, which is associated with periodontal diseases (86). In the family Succinivibrionaceae, the genus Anaerobiospirillum includes two species, A. thomasii and A. succiniciproducens, isolated from feces of humans, cats, and dogs (87) but the latter species has also been isolated from prosthetic joint infections (88), while the genus Succinatimonas has one species, S. hippei, isolated from human feces (89). S. hippei is nonmotile and has nonspiral cells without flagella, whereas Anaerobiospirillum, Desulfovibrio (except D. piger), and Desulfomicrobium are motile, spiral-shaped bacteria that reduce sulfate.

Since 2002, genome projects have produced a tremendous number of complete genome sequences for a variety of Gram-negative anaerobic species, including members of almost all the genera discussed in this chapter. Readers are directed to the NCBI homepage (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome/browse/) for detailed information. Interestingly, the genome sequence for F. nucleatum revealed that although this species has a Gram-negative cell wall, including an outer membrane, a significant proportion of genes were related to homologues from Gram-positive species in the phylum Firmicutes, suggesting that Fusobacterium has a Gram-positive evolutionary history (90).

Current methods used for taxonomic studies are mainly based on nucleic acid analyses, in particular, sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene and the comparison of these sequences in order to reveal the phylogenetic relatedness of taxa. Multilocus sequence typing, average-nucleotide-identity analyses, and genome-to-genome distance analyses have been introduced and might supplement or even replace DNA-DNA hybridization to delineate bacteria at the species level. These approaches do not necessarily correlate with phenotypic characteristics, such as cell and colony morphologies, atmospheric growth requirements, and various biochemical test results, which are still widely used in clinical microbiology laboratories. However, appropriate atmospheric requirements should be determined for all isolates, because the true anaerobes can be differentiated from facultatively anaerobic bacteria by their inability to grow in the presence of oxygen and by their susceptibility to metronidazole (91). Table 2 presents differential characteristics of clinically relevant genera within the Gram-negative anaerobic rods.

Since the preparation of the last edition of thisManual, many additional candidate species were isolated from various clinical sites by a culturomics approach. We, the authors and editors of this chapter, decided not to include these candidate species, in most cases based on a single isolate, before their names are approved and/or their clinical significance is validated. However, without any doubt, and as we know from the “great plate count anomaly,” there are many additional new species out there (92).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Gram-negative anaerobic rods inhabit the mucosal surfaces of the oral cavity and gastrointestinal tract of animals and humans. Infants acquire oral and intestinal anaerobic commensals mainly from their mother and become simultaneously colonized by multiple strains of commensal species, e.g.,Prevotella melaninogenica, Fusobacterium nucleatum, or Bacteroides fragilis (93–95). In fact, some of these organisms, such as Fusobacterium and Prevotella, are ubiquitous members of the mouth from the early months of life and, when teeth erupt, form integral parts of dental biofilms (93, 96). Furthermore, Prevotella has been shown among the dominant genera in other habitats, such as the esophagus, stomach, and lungs (97–99), which have previously been considered to have a very limited microbial diversity. Interestingly, in non-Westernized populations consuming fresh, unprocessed food, intestinal Prevotella species are common, playing an important role in nutrition and metabolism (100). In the gut, Bacteroides becomes part of the microbiota in early infancy (95), although as a result of cesarean section, the colonization of the B. fragilis group organisms can be delayed and the levels are greatly reduced (101). Moreover, the composition of Bacteroides populations varies depending on the type of milk-feeding (102). Two bacterial phyla, Firmicutes and Bacteroidetes, dominate in the gut. Changes in the microbial composition affect the gut barrier function with consequences for host physiology, energy balance (obesity risk), or mucosal immune system. In this context, Gram-negative anaerobes play a key role (2, 103). In the female genital tract, when the vaginal hydrogen peroxide-producing lactobacilli decrease in numbers, some Prevotella species increase and become an important part with other commensal vaginosis-associated microorganisms (104, 105). Notably, the microbiotas at different body sites are still poorly defined due to considerable proportions of not-yet-cultivated bacteria (71, 106–108).

Also, an important point to be mentioned is the considerable variation observed in the microbiotas due to geographical and ethnic differences. This variation clearly influences the recovery rates of disease-associated organisms in different populations (105, 109–111).

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: Anaerobes, originating mainly from the indigenous microbiota, are detected typically in polymicrobial infections associated with mucosal surfaces close to the site where they reside. Most infections are acquired when the integrity of the colonized mucosa or lumen is breached by trauma or underlying disease or during surgery. Biofilm-associated infections, such as periodontitis and bacterial vaginosis, occur when certain indigenous organisms with virulent properties are enriched within subgingival or vaginal biofilms, respectively, thus causing dysbiosis of the local microbiota (105). Exceptions to the endogenous acquisition include clenched-fist wounds contaminated by human oral microbiota as well as animal and human bite wounds. Gram-negative anaerobes, such as B. fragilis, are involved in a variety of infections with a considerable morbidity and mortality (2). Table 3 summarizes the infectious sites where Gram-negative anaerobic organisms have been frequently isolated from clinical specimens. They can occasionally spread to adjacent tissues and the bloodstream with serious consequences. Localized dentoalveolar infections can result in life-threatening spread of oral anaerobes along tissue spaces of the head and neck down to the mediastinum (112). In cases in which Gram-negative anaerobes gain entrance to the bloodstream and trigger a systemic inflammatory response, this may result in sepsis or infective endocarditis with a fatal outcome. The gastrointestinal tract and the oropharynx are the most common sources for anaerobic bacteremia by Gram-negative anaerobes, with gastrointestinal surgery and underlying malignancies being the major predisposing factors (113–115). Interestingly, the risk of bacteremia in patients with an inflamed gut, e.g., with inflammatory bowel disease, is usually as low as a few percentages (116). In contrast, in the oral cavity, inflamed periodontal tissues are a well-known portal of frequent entry for myriad oral anaerobes to the circulation via daily practices of oral hygiene and chewing food (117, 118). A recent next-generation sequencing (NGS) investigation of blood bacterial communities showed that 43 to 52% of bacterial species and 88% of bacterial sequences in blood were of oral origin, and a minor proportion were of skin, gut, or genital tract origin (119). This calls attention to the importance of prevention of oral infections, especially in patients at increased risk for infective endocarditis.

sect1.title: Bacteroides and Related Genera
sect1.para: Among the anaerobes in clinical specimens, members of the bile-resistantB. fragilis group are the most commonly encountered and are more virulent and resistant to antimicrobial agents than most other anaerobes. Although other intestinal Bacteroides species outnumber B. fragilis 10- to 100-fold, B. fragilis has proven to be the most frequent Bacteroides found in specimens from blood, ulcers, abscesses, cellulitis, bronchial secretion, bone, intra-abdominal infections, and inflamed appendix (2). In the Wadsworth Anaerobe Collection database, consisting of more than 3,000 clinical specimens, B. thetaiotaomicron and B. ovatus were also detected in these specimens, but less frequently. A large U.S. study series that included over 6,500 isolates of the B. fragilis group from clinical specimens, collected yearly between 1997 and 2007, confirmed this: B. fragilis was most common (51%), followed by B. thetaiotaomicron (19%) and B. ovatus (10%) (120). Similar percentages were found for these three species in a Belgian hospital survey on anaerobic bacteremias between 2004 and 2013 (121). Most isolates came from blood and intra-abdominal infections. In children, B. fragilis is the main anaerobic organism recovered from intra-abdominal infections (2, 122); for instance, it is isolated from nearly all tissue specimens of acute appendicitis (123). Around 10 to 20% of the B. fragilis strains are able to produce enterotoxin encoded by the bft1 through bft3 genes; these strains have been associated with diarrhea in children as well as in adults, and in addition, their proportion seems to be higher than that of nontoxigenic strains among blood culture isolates (124). The B. fragilis group organisms (here also including Parabacteroides distasonis) and other Bacteroides species are the most frequently isolated pathogens from bloodstream infections with involvement of anaerobes (2, 113–115, 125). In a population-based 9-year retrospective analysis on anaerobic bloodstream infections conducted in the province of Alberta, Canada, the B. fragilis group accounted for 277 (31%) of the 904 cases (115). Comorbidities, especially colorectal cancer, formed a common risk factor for anaerobic bacteremia. On the other hand, enterotoxigenic B. fragilis may play a yet-to-be-confirmed role in the etiology of colorectal cancer (126–128). Bloodstream infections of several other Bacteroides species, such as B. caccae, B. denticani, B. dorei, B. faecis, B. finegoldii, and B. nordii, have been reported (125, 129–131). Bacteroides involvement in infective endocarditis, where B. fragilis of gastrointestinal origin is the most frequent finding, tends to be more serious than that of other anaerobes, sometimes with fatal outcome (132). The B. fragilis group has been recovered from pericarditis samples (133) and, often as a single isolate, from septic arthritis as well as from osteomyelitis samples (134). Although spondylodiscitis caused by anaerobes is not common, the involvement of B. fragilis needs to be taken into account in cases with potential bacteremia of intestinal origin or after surgery (135, 136). In peritoneal dialysis patients, anaerobic peritonitis is a rare event; however, B. fragilis and B. thetaiotaomicron have been isolated (137). By hematogeneous spread, the B. fragilis group and other Bacteroides organisms can reach the brain, causing abscesses (138–140). In addition, members of this group are among the predominant isolates from burn wound infections, with potential involvement in sepsis in this context (141). Bacteroides species can be involved in part in polymicrobial necrotizing soft tissue infections (2), and the B. fragilis group is, after Gram-positive anaerobic cocci, one of the most common anaerobes found in infected moderate to severe diabetic foot wounds (142, 143). In cat and dog bite infections, B. pyogenes and B. tectum can be found (144, 145), but a B. pyogenes liver abscess and subsequent bacteremia with no history of animal bite was recently described (146).

Pigmented, bile-resistantAlistipes species, A. finegoldii, A. onderdonkii, and A. shahii, have been strongly connected to appendicitis, both in children and in adults (8, 123). In addition, all three species have been isolated from intra-abdominal fluid or abscesses and A. onderdonkii (recently divided into two subspecies) also from urine (8, 125, 147). There is one report with two cases on the detection of A. finegoldii in blood (148); by phylogenetic reanalysis, one isolate was later identified as A. onderdonkii (147). Alistipes may have protective effects against some diseases. Its association with colorectal cancer or depression (149) needs verification.

sect1.title: Porphyromonas and Related Genera
sect1.para: Pathogenic potential varies between differentPorphyromonas species. Of the four oral Porphyromonas species, P. endodontalis and P. gingivalis are known as significant pathogens. The detection rate of P. gingivalis, one of the major periodontal pathogens, increases with age (150, 151). In addition to periodontitis, it has been frequently detected in oral specimens from necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis, infected root canals, peri-implant lesions, and acute apical abscesses (110, 152, 153). Besides the oral cavity, it has been detected in clinical specimens from various body sites, e.g., intra-abdominal sites (154), vaginal samples in women with bacterial vaginosis (155), amniotic fluid (156), synovial specimens of rheumatoid arthritis, and psoriatic arthritis (157) and, together with some other periodontal organisms, in occluded arteries of lower extremities of Buerger’s disease patients (158). Recently investigated links between P. gingivalis and age-related macular degeneration (159), adverse pregnancy outcomes (160), Alzheimer’s disease (161, 162), atherosclerotic disease (163), and cancer (164) need confirmation. P. endodontalis is one of the dominant organisms in infected root canals and in acute dental abscesses (108, 152, 165), but may also be involved in chronic periodontitis (166). P. uenonis, which is phenotypically similar to P. endodontalis and P. asaccharolytica, has been detected in polymicrobial infections below the waistline: appendicitis, peritonitis, pilonidal abscess, an infected sacral decubitus ulcer, and bacterial vaginosis (9, 167). P. asaccharolytica and P. somerae were among the anaerobic isolates from moderate to severe diabetic foot infections (142). At the VA Wadsworth Medical Center laboratory, 58 P. somerae isolates originated from a variety of specimens, including lower extremity skin and soft tissue or bone, abscesses of the inguinal or sacral area, intra-abdominal abscess, transtracheal aspirate, axillary abscess, mastoiditis, blood culture, brain tissue, and infected scalp (presented in order of their frequency) (11). P. bennonis has been detected in human wound infections and abscesses, especially in patients with chronic skin and soft tissue lesions in the perirectal, buttock, and groin regions (12). Although P. catoniae inhabits the oral cavity without any disease association described to date, it has been isolated from an abdominal abscess (10). Porphyromonas species of animal origin, e.g., P. cangingivalis, P. canoris, P. cansulci, P. gulae, P. macacae, and P. pogonae, have been encountered in humans, in most cases after animal bite infections (17, 18, 145).

Parabacteroides species are common inhabitants of the human gut, and P. distasonis is one of the anaerobes of clinical importance in specimens from intra-abdominal infections and inflamed appendixes, where P. goldsteinii and P. merdae can also be found (2, 168). A few cases of splenic abscess formation by P. distasonis are described (169). In addition, P. distasonis, P. merdae, P. goldsteinii, P. gordonii, and the novel P. chongii have been isolated from human blood (2, 20, 125, 170–172). Recently, P. goldsteinii was isolated from a case of abdominal infection in a patient with lymphoma (173).

Tannerella forsythia is considered one of the major periodontal pathogens (150, 174). In addition, it is one of the predominant organisms in root canal infections (110, 165) and has been found in infected sites around dental implants (153). Moreover, T. forsythia can be recovered in substantial amounts from tonsillar crypts of adults (107). In laryngectomized patients with voice rehabilitation, T. forsythia proved to be one of the main biofilm-forming anaerobes on voice prostheses that needed replacement (175). This oral bacterium has also been recovered from vaginal samples in women with bacterial vaginosis (155) as well as from synovial specimens of patients with rheumatoid or psoriatic arthritis (157).

sect1.title: Prevotella and Related Genera
sect1.para: Prevotella species are among the dominant microorganisms of the oral cavity, where they, despite their commensalism, can be involved in nearly all types of oral infections. Interestingly, P. melaninogenica, which is a common anaerobic organism in saliva (93), is also one of the most prevalent anaerobes, together with F. nucleatum, P. intermedia, and P. buccae, in infected human bite lesions (176). Although the cariogenic microbiota mainly consists of Gram-positive species, some proteolytic Gram-negative taxa, including P. denticola and P. tannerae (currently Alloprevotella tannerae), can be frequently encountered in advanced carious lesions (177). P. intermedia has been strongly linked to periodontitis (109, 151), and P. intermedia and/or the phenotypically identical P. nigrescens has been detected in samples from dentoalveolar abscesses, necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis, pericoronitis, peri-implantitis, pregnancy gingivitis, root canal infections, and—as one of the rare extraoral examples—from costochondritis (110, 152–154, 178, 179). Also, P. baroniae proved to be common in root canal infections and acute dental abscess aspirates (110, 165). In noma (cancrum oris), P. intermedia is considered a key organism (180, 181). In spreading odontogenic infections, members of the genus Prevotella seem to play an important role, with P. buccae and P. oris the most prominent organisms in this context (112, 182–184). P. melaninogenica/P. histicola were found to be significantly associated with recurrent tonsillitis in adults (107). P. pleuritidis, originally isolated from pleural fluid, was recently isolated from lung abscess (43, 185). A new concept of the polymicrobial bacteriology of cystic fibrosis has been presented, and indeed, not only aerobic Pseudomonas aeruginosa or Staphylococcus aureus, but also some anaerobes—especially Prevotella, such as P. melaninogenica, P. denticola, P. oris, and P. salivae—have been detected as among the persistently dominating organisms in the sputum of these patients (186). Also, Prevotella taxa were recovered from bronchoalveolar lavage of ventilator-associated pneumonia (187). Furthermore, various Prevotella species are found in extraoral infections and abscesses at a wide range of body sites, for instance, P. amnii, P. bivia, P. corporis, P. disiens, P. intermedia, P. lascolaii (new species), P. nigrescens, and P. timonensis in the female genital tract (42, 105, 155); P. buccalis in urine (188); P. bergensis, P. bivia, and P. melaninogenica in infectious lesions of the skin and soft tissues, including diabetic foot lesions (39, 142); P. intermedia and P. nigrescens from intra-abdominal and soft tissue abscesses (154); P. intermedia (sensu lato) and P. melaninogenica from peritonsillar and retropharyngeal abscesses; P. timonensis from breast abscesses as well as genital and wound origins (40, 189); P. intermedia in synovial fluid of arthritis patients (157); and P. intermedia and P. nigrescens (with some other periodontal bacteria) in occluded arteries of lower extremities of Buerger’s disease patients (158). The newly described P. colorans strain was isolated from a wound specimen as part of a polymicrobial infection (190). Several Prevotella species, such as P. bivia, P. buccae, P. denticola, P. disiens, and P. nigrescens, have been among anaerobic findings in bloodstream infections (125, 154). Increased P. bivia abundance has been found associated with severe preeclampsia, a pregnancy complication (191). The first clinical case of P. copri was reported from blood of an elderly patient with a Prevotella-dominated gut microbiome (192). P. heparinolytica is a relatively common anaerobic isolate from animal bite wounds (145). With increasing use of sequencing techniques, obligate anaerobic Gram-negative rods are increasingly detected in clinical infections, such as brain or liver abscesses with Prevotella and Fusobacterium species predominating (193, 194). The related genus and species Phocaeicola abscessus was isolated from a human brain abscess sample and was recently discovered in symptomatic primary endodontic infection as well (195, 196).

sect1.title: Fusobacterium and Related Genera
sect1.para: Clinically, the most importantFusobacterium species are F. nucleatum and F. necrophorum (197–199). Over the past few years, there has been an increased interest directed to the role of fusobacteria in human infections, especially recurrent tonsillitis, Lemierre’s syndrome, brain abscesses, and bacteremia (107, 194, 200–204), but also in diseases not usually regarded as typical infections, such as acute appendicitis, inflammatory bowel disease, and colon cancer (205–207). Moreover, in children, fusobacterial infections of otogenic origin deserve attention due to potential invasive complications (208, 209).

F. nucleatum is an oral species, which has been divided into several subspecies with variable pathogenic potentials. It is a key organism in maturation of pathogenic biofilms in periodontal pockets and is considered an important pathogen in peri-implantitis, root canal infections, dentoalveolar abscesses, human bite wounds, and spreading odontogenic infections (110, 153, 165, 182). F. nucleatum was found as a dominant species in tonsillar crypts (107), which may explain its dominance in biofilms on voice prostheses that needed replacement (175). It is also an important etiologic agent in extraoral infections and abscesses at a wide range of body sites, being detected from blood, brain, chest, heart, lung, liver, appendix, (prosthetic) joint, long bone, abdomen, gut, genitourinary tract, and fetal membranes (123, 125, 133, 134, 138, 176, 188, 198, 200, 203–205, 207, 210–216). Recently, mechanistic evidence for its implication in adverse pregnancy outcomes was described (217). People with bacteremia from F. nucleatum often have underlying comorbidities (200, 203, 204). Health care-related F. nucleatum bacteremia is associated with increased mortality (204). In a tertiary care hospital where all episodes of documented brain abscess cases between 1991 and 2000 were reviewed, in 40% of cerebral puncture specimens, only anaerobes were found; of these, F. nucleatum proved to be the most frequently isolated organism, found in one of three patients (138). In another study, using molecular methods for bacterial detection in 51 brain abscess pus specimens, F. nucleatum was among the most frequent findings, especially in patients with preceding sinusitis or dental treatment (210). In a Norwegian multicenter study over a period of 2 years in five university hospitals, fusobacteria, mainly F. nucleatum, were detected in 19 out of 20 brain abscesses with anaerobic bacteria (194). The presence of Fusobacterium adhesin A seems to allow separation of F. nucleatum (together with oral F. periodonticum and F. simiae) from nonoral fusobacterial species (F. gonidiaformans, F. mortiferum, F. russii, and F. ulcerans) (218). There is increasing evidence that F. nucleatum is not only a passenger but coinducer of oral (219), breast (220), and colorectal (59, 206, 221) cancers. As potential mechanisms, an excessive inflammatory reaction, suppression of apoptosis, promotion of malignant transformation, and chemoresistance by modulation of autophagy were investigated and—at least partially—proven (222–224).

Of the twoF. necrophorum subspecies, F. necrophorum subsp. funduliforme (biovar B) is the dominant isolate in humans, while F. necrophorum subsp. necrophorum is a common pathogen in animals (197, 199). Important virulence factors, explaining the invasiveness of F. necrophorum, are leukotoxin and plasminogen binding (225). F. necrophorum is best known for its connection to Lemierre’s syndrome (necrobacillosis), which can be considered an invasive F. necrophorum disease, often with pleuropulmonary involvement, in previously healthy adolescents, young adults, and pediatric populations (197, 199, 201, 202, 226, 227). It is notable that invasive disease with F. necrophorum may be on the increase (197). In Denmark, the overall mortality of Lemierre’s syndrome, originating mainly from oropharyngeal sites, was reported to be 9% in adolescents, and that of disseminated F. necrophorum infections, originating from lower parts of the body, was 26% in elderly patients with predisposing diseases (226). In the latter type of cases, underlying cancers should be considered. Interestingly, F. necrophorum can be found in adolescents as the causative agent in approximately 10% of the cases of tonsillitis (persistent sore throat) not caused by group A streptococci (197, 199, 228). In a Danish retrospective study, including 847 patients with peritonsillar abscesses in the years 2001 to 2006, F. necrophorum was detected in 23% of the pus aspirate or swab specimens, most of them growing as a pure culture (229). Another Danish study among 1,930 throat swabs, taken from 15- to 24-year-old patients by general practitioners between 2007 and 2009, reported the detection rate of 22% for F. necrophorum (230). A wide variety of infections can be caused by F. necrophorum; in the head and neck: tonsillitis, peritonsillar abscess, deep neck space infection, mediastinitis, otogenic infection, mastoiditis, sinusitis, and odontogenic infection; as intracranial complications: sinus thrombosis, cerebral and epidural abscesses, and meningitis; and as systemic manifestations: bacteremia, septicemia, pleuropulmonary infections, bone and joint infections, soft tissue infections, liver abscess, intra-abdominal sepsis, pelvic peritonitis, endocarditis, and pericarditis (199–203, 208, 209, 229, 231–234).

OtherFusobacterium taxa, such as F. gonidiaformans, F. necrogenes, F. ulcerans, and the F. mortiferum-F. varium group, have been only occasionally isolated from human clinical specimens (122, 142, 198, 208, 235–237). F. nucleatum and the closely related species of animal origin, F. canifelinum and F. russii, are of importance in cats and dogs as well as in the bite wounds of these pets in humans (145, 238). F. russii was isolated from a deep forefoot ulcer of a patient with close contacts to cats, but apart from some scratches the patient denied any bite injuries (239). F. canifelinum sequences were detected also in the human oral cavity (240), but this needs confirmation. However, pet owners might not be astonished about this fact.

CommensalLeptotrichia species are increasingly implicated in anaerobic bacteremias in immunocompromised patients with lesions of the oral or gastrointestinal mucosa but are also occasionally considered etiologic agents of bacteremia and infective endocarditis in immunocompetent individuals (113, 241–246). L. buccalis, L. goodfellowii, L. trevisanii, and L. wadei are the main Leptotrichia species in blood specimens. According to a 5-year retrospective analysis on Leptotrichia organisms in a national reference laboratory in Utah where 51 isolates were identified to species level, L. trevisanii comprised 47%, L. goodfellowii, L. wadei, and L. hongkongensis each 9%, and L. buccalis 1.5% of the 68 Leptotrichia-positive cultures (243). Interestingly, L. hongkongensis was isolated especially from multiple myeloma patients. In an immunocompetent subject, L. wadei was reported as a causative organism of a severe pneumonia (247). In the female genital tract, some infectious cases, including bacterial vaginosis, intrauterine fetal demise, and septic abortion, have been reported in connection with L. trevisanii (248) and “L. amnionii,” a candidate species also known as Sneathia amnii and recently reclassified as Sneathia vaginalis (62, 105, 167, 211, 249). In fact, this organism significantly associates with all four Amsel’s criteria (pH, Whiff test, vaginal discharge, clue cells) used in clinical diagnostics of bacterial vaginosis (105). Furthermore, a few bacteremia cases in connection to delivery (250) and one neonatal meningitis case (251) have been reported. However, it has also been isolated from a knee joint specimen of a male patient (252), revealing that the organism is not restricted to the female genital tract. Based on the high number of S. vaginalis in urine samples from renal transplant recipients, it may also be considered one of the etiologic agents of urinary tract infections (188). One case of septic arthritis with an involvement of other Sneathia species, most closely related to S. sanguinegens, has been reported in an immunocompetent woman (253). Although S. sanguinegens was originally isolated from blood (254), it has been mainly reported from various infectious conditions of the female genital tract, such as preterm labor, neonatal sepsis, postpartum bacteremia and prosthetic valve infective endocarditis, and pyosalpinx, and in amniotic fluid associated with various clinical syndromes (167, 211, 214, 250, 254, 255). Using metagenomic 16S rRNA gene identification for Sneathia in mid-vaginal samples from 736 women in an urban outpatient clinic in Virginia, the target organism was detected in 30 to 43% of the samples, depending on the selected abundance treshold (64). It was also shown that S. vaginalis (under the former name S. amnii) is able to adhere to the cervical epithelium and, presumably, to invade the uterine cavity. Leptotrichia/Sneathia can be considered clinically relevant intra-amniotic pathogens (211, 212), and, in fact, their role in adverse perinatal outcomes, including preterm labor, was underestimated until recently (256).

sect1.title: Other Anaerobic Gram-Negative Rods
sect1.para: In the novel phylumSynergistetes, six cultivable species representing five genera, i.e., Fretibacterium fastidiosum, Jonquetella anthropi, Pyramidobacter piscolens, and the recently discovered Rarimicrobium hominis (68), as well as Cloacibacillus evryensis and C. porcorum (69), have been isolated from human clinical specimens. J. anthropi isolates came from breast abscess, pelvic abscess, sebaceous cyst, wound, and peritoneal fluid specimens (66), while F. fastidiosum and P. piscolens were found in periodontitis, dental root canals, and odontogenic abscesses (65, 67, 110). Clinical R. hominis isolates came from gynecological surgery material, parietal abscess, sacrum, and perianal abscess specimens (68), and C. evryensis and C. porcorum isolates from blood (69).

TwoDialister species, D. pneumosintes and D. invisus, are inhabitants of the oral cavity, where they have been implicated as pathogens in endodontal and periodontal infections as well as acute dental abscesses and sinusitis (73, 110, 257–259). In addition, they have been recovered from blood, abscesses (brain, neck/mediastinal, hepatic, Bartholin’s), bronchoalveolar lavage of ventilator-associated pneumonia and cystic fibrosis, urine, and human bite wounds (117, 176, 186–188, 260–264). A considerable number of D. pneumosintes isolates originate from various cutaneous/soft tissue infections (260). It may be that the patient’s poor dental hygiene is a predisposing factor in certain nonoral cases, e.g., bacteremia and brain abscess (187, 261). D. micraerophilus, which is not a strict anaerobe, D. propionicifaciens, and—recently—D. hominis have been isolated from a variety of clinical specimens, mainly below the waistline (74, 75, 105, 260).

Selenomonas species and Centipeda periodontii (also a member of Selenomonadaceae) are motile organisms recovered from the oral cavity, where they are components of dental biofilms (84, 265, 266). S. sputigena has been found in specimens from necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis, generalized aggressive periodontitis, and acute dental abscesses (109, 110). S. noxia has been reported in chronic and aggressive periodontitis lesions (109). C. periodontii has been recovered from endodontic infections (266). Furthermore, there have been a few reports on the involvement of Selenomonas in nonoral infections, including cystic fibrosis and bacteremia (186).

OccasionalPhascolarctobacterium findings, identified as P. faecium (an animal-derived, koala associated species), have been reported from anaerobic bacteremia cases in humans (121). These isolates may represent P. succinatutens, which was later isolated and characterized from human feces (78).
Recently, the first clinical case with involvement ofChristensella minuta, together with Desulfovibrio desulfuricans, was reported in blood of a patient suffering from acute appendicitis (80).

Sutterella wadsworthensis, a microaerobic organism phenotypically but not phylogenetically close to fastidious Campylobacter species, has been isolated from a variety of infections, such as appendicitis, peritonitis, and rectal or perirectal abscesses (267). Sutterella was suggested to play a dominant role in gastrointestinal disturbances in children with autism (268), but this needs confirmation.

Bilophila wadsworthia is a significant human pathogen in polymicrobial intra-abdominal infections, especially in appendicitis, at an increasing frequency with deteriorating disease status (84). In gangrenous appendices of children, B. wadsworthia is even more common than in those of adults (123). Moreover, B. wadsworthia has been isolated from abscesses at various body sites as well as from blood (84, 269).

SomeAnaerobiospirillum and Desulfovibrio organisms reside in the gastrointestinal tract of humans and can also be infrequently encountered in clinical specimens; typical cases are bacteremia and abdominal infections in immunocompromised patients (85, 270–272). Of the two Anaerobiospirillum species, A. succiniciproducens has been connected to bacteremia, diarrheal illness, and prosthetic joint infections, whereas A. thomasii is considered a potential cause of diarrhea but not of bacteremia (87, 88, 273–276). In the case of diarrhea and sepsis, the possibility of zoonotic transmission exists (271, 276). The main Desulfovibrio species isolated from human infections include D. desulfuricans, “D. fairfieldensis,” D. piger, and D. vulgaris (85, 277–279). D. desulfuricans is common also in the environment, whereas “D. fairfieldensis” and D. piger have been detected only in humans so far. The first human findings of D. intestinalis came from vaginal specimens of four Japanese women (280). “D. fairfieldensis,” a taxon never validly described, has been isolated from blood in particular, but also from various intra-abdominal sites, urine, and periodontal pockets (278). D. desulfuricans bacteremia cases are mainly connected to abdominal illnesses (281–283), and a case of liver abscess (in coculture with Escherichia coli) was described recently (284). In addition to “D. fairfieldensis,” an oral Desulfomicrobium species, D. orale, has been connected to periodontitis (86). On the basis of differences in pyrosequencing results of stools collected from autistic children with gastrointestinal symptoms and their sibling and nonsibling controls, Desulfovibrio was suggested to be linked to regressive autism (285), but this needs confirmation. Together with methanogens, sulfate reducers such as Desulfovibrio consume the end product H2, forming a “hydrogen sink” and enhancing the fermentation and growth of bacteria in anaerobic (infectious) processes, as an interesting concept of pathogenicity (111, 286).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: General guidelines for collection, transport, and storage of specimens are discussed inchapters 13 and 19 of this Manual. Specimens suitable for the isolation of anaerobes include blood, tissue biopsies, aspirates (e.g., cerebrospinal fluid, joint fluids, and pus), dental root canal exudates, and subgingival plaque (exclusively from the base level of the periodontal pocket). Appropriate respiratory tract specimens include bronchoscopic protected-brush specimens, centesis samples from the thoracic/pleural cavity, percutaneous transtracheal aspirates, and lung tissue biopsies acquired at surgery or autopsy. Also, wound and ulcer specimens should preferably be taken by tissue biopsy, wound curettage, or aspiration. For example, for diabetic foot ulcers, the lesion is cleaned and carefully debrided, and tissue samples are collected from the base or progressive edge, where bacteria actively multiply (142). Infected tissue, obtained by excision or biopsy, is always preferable to pus as a clinical specimen. However, when pus is collected, it is best aspirated into a syringe through a needle and injected into an anaerobic transport vial containing an oxidation-reduction indicator (e.g., products from Anaerobe Systems, Morgan Hill, CA, and Becton Dickinson, Sparks, MD). It is notable that syringes used for aspiration should not be used as transporters because of the potential danger of needle stick injuries or accidental expulsion and because oxygen diffuses through plastic syringes (91). Mucosal or cutaneous swabs are not recommended. In cases where bacteremia is suspected, culture of 20 ml of blood (at least two separate samples) is recommended. Anaerobic culture is important, especially in patients with complex underlying diseases and when the source of bacteremia is unknown (114). Also, blood collected from patients with abdominal or gynecological processes, peritoneal abscess, dirty wound, decubitus ulcers, osteomyelitis, or spreading oropharyngeal disease should be examined for anaerobes.

Specimens must be transported to the laboratory under anaerobic conditions (e.g., Anaerobe Systems PRAS Anaerobic Transport Media [ATM] AS-911, [ATMSurgeryPack] AS-914, or [DentalTM] AS-920; Becton Dickinson BBL Port-A-Cul Transport Systems; BBL Vacutainer Anaerobic Specimen Collector [media-free in order to minimize sample dilution]; or AnaeroGRO of Hardy Diagnostics, Santa Maria, CA) without delay for further processing. An optimal transport system is able to maintain the viability of anaerobic organisms without allowing the overgrowth of aerobic bacteria. However, if clinical specimens contain fastidious organisms, the transport to the clinical laboratory should occur within 24 h (287). Tissue samples are best transported in specific anaerobic transport vials or in loosely capped containers sealed in gas-impermeable bags in which an anaerobic atmosphere has been generated. For small tissue and biopsy specimens and for subgingival and dental root canal samples, a semisolid anaerobic transport medium (e.g., those of Anaerobe Systems, Becton Dickinson, and Hardy Diagnostics), in which the specimen can be submerged, can be used.
Further guidance for the collection of specimens from different body sites and by various methods, as well as transport systems and anaerobic techniques, can be found in more detail elsewhere (91).

For long-term storage, 2- to 3-day-old cultures can be transferred into vials containing sterilized 20% skim milk and kept frozen at –70°C. Another freezing method is to mix four parts of a 48-h broth culture, such as cooked-meat medium without glucose, with sterile glycerol (final concentration, 10 to 25%), and pipette into a sterile vial.

sect2.title: DIRECT EXAMINATION
sect2.para: The gross appearance, fluorescence under long-wave UV light, and odor of the specimen can give the laboratory valuable clues to the presence of anaerobes. A fetid or putrid odor due to volatile short-chain fatty acids and amines is always associated with the presence of anaerobes in the sample. Black necrotic tissue and/or red fluorescence of the sample may be indicative of the presence of pigmented Gram-negative rods (91).

The Gram stain is quick, simple, and likely to yield significant information, and one should be prepared from all specimens accepted for anaerobic culture. Many Gram-negative anaerobic rods have unique cell morphology, e.g., different species within the genusFusobacterium. For instance, a Gram-stained smear with highly pleomorphic Gram-negative rods in a positive blood culture bottle from a septic patient following a sore throat may indicate invasive F. necrophorum infection (197). The morphotypes and relative quantities of the bacteria and host inflammatory cells present in the preparation should be reported. Gram stain using the Nugent criteria for interpretation of vaginal discharge is still considered the best method for diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis (104). However, nucleic acid amplification test measurements of the abundance of normal and dysbiotic microbiota, relative to total bacteria in vaginal fluid, may provide a more accurate diagnosis (288).

sect1.title: Molecular Detection
sect1.para: Molecular methods are nowadays commonly used for direct detection of bacteria from clinical specimens or for confirmation of identity. Almost complete or partial (the V3 through V6 regions are the most informative) sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene is successfully used for identifying fastidious organisms and potential pathogens in typical polymicrobial lesions such as periodontitis, endodontic infections, and spreading odontogenic infections (70, 108, 166, 182), but also in infections where the involvement of anaerobic bacteria has not been traditionally taken into account, e.g., cystic fibrosis (186). It is notable that a culture-based approach can underestimate the presence of etiologic but fastidious or uncultivable organisms in clinical specimens. For example, Prevotella species are highly prevalent in the lungs of cystic fibrosis patients (186, 289), but routine culture of sputum does not include anaerobes and potential anaerobic pathogens are not reported. Furthermore, in women who experienced preterm labor and whose amniotic fluid tested positive by culture or PCR, seven species, including Sneathia sanguinegens and S. vaginalis (formerly S. amnii or “Leptotrichia amnionii”), were detected by PCR only (211). A molecular-based and FDA-approved test using vaginal swabs collected by clinicians or patients was found to accurately diagnose most common bacterial, fungal, and protozoan causes of vaginitis (290). In addition, in a study of urinary tract specimens from renal transplant recipients (188), the 16S rRNA PCR method detected a wide range of bacteria, including Gram-negative anaerobes such as B. vulgatus, D. invisus, F. nucleatum, S. vaginalis (“L. amnionii”), P. buccalis, and P. ruminicola, in culture-negative samples. A study that subjected pus specimens from 51 brain abscesses to 16S rRNA gene amplification, cloning, and sequencing revealed 19 cases of polymicrobial infections with 76 different species, including 22 uncultured taxa, among them 10 Bacteroides phylotypes (210). A study applying massive parallel sequencing on samples from 52 brain abscesses, categorized as either spontaneous intracerebral, spontaneous subdural, or postoperative, demonstrated Fusobacterium and Prevotella among the top 10 species detectable (194). An increasing number of metagenomics deep-sequencing studies have demonstrated that the species diversity in such polymicrobial infections is much richer than previously assumed. With decreasing prices and new methods, e.g., bar code labeling and V6 tagging, next-generation sequencing will expand the power to investigate health- and disease-associated mixed anaerobic microbial communities or outbreak history (291–293). Challenges associated with molecular techniques include exclusion of any contamination (sampling, transport, processing stages), differences in the lysis efficiency depending on the bacterial cell wall composition, human competitor DNA in clinical samples, primer discrimination because of mismatches or limited accessibility of template site, persistence of DNA of dead cells, inability of the antimicrobial susceptibility testing, and interpretation of complex results and clinical consequences (294–296).

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Except for blood and joint fluid cultures, the use of liquid medium as the only anaerobic culture technique is not acceptable (91). The use of solid nonselective medium together with selective medium increases the yield and saves time in terms of recognition and isolation of colonies. The selective media are chosen based on the expected microbiota at the collection site, or in the case of bite wounds, on the oral microbiota of the biter (human or animal). Freshly prepared or prereduced and anaerobically sterilized medium should be used (91). Different basal media differ in their abilities to support the growth of anaerobes; brucella base and Fastidious Anaerobe Agar (Lab M, Bury, United Kingdom) may be the best basal medium for isolation of Gram-negative anaerobic rods. In particular, Fastidious Anaerobe Agar enhances the growth of fusobacteria (197). In academic centers performing large-scale anaerobic bacteriology, it would be ideal to use two different basal media to maximize isolation efficiency.

Culture methods in general are discussed inchapter 19 Manual. The minimum medium setup for isolating Gram-negative anaerobic rods includes (i) a nonselective, enriched, brucella base sheep blood agar plate supplemented with vitamin K1 and hemin (BA); (ii) a kanamycin-vancomycin laked sheep blood agar plate for the selection of Bacteroides and Prevotella species; and (iii) a Bacteroides bile-esculin (BBE) agar plate for specimens from areas below the diaphragm for the selection and presumptive identification of the B. fragilis group and Bilophila species. BBE and kanamycin-vancomycin laked sheep blood are also available as biplates. A phenylethyl alcohol sheep blood agar plate used to prevent overgrowth by aerobic Gram-negative rods and swarming of some clostridia is indicated for purulent specimens and in the case of mixed infections. Use of a metronidazole disk (5 μg) on nonselective agar is useful for the detection of Gram-negative obligate anaerobes; however, it may mask the presence of infrequently encountered metronidazole-resistant organisms.

After inoculation, the anaerobic plates are immediately incubated at 36 to 37°C in an anaerobic environment, such as an anaerobic bag, jar, or chamber. Alternatively, setup and incubation may all be done in an anaerobic chamber. Plates should not be exposed to air during the first 48 h, to avoid loss of the more oxygen-sensitive species. The availability of an anaerobic chamber enables the examination of the culture whenever necessary. An incubation period of 48 h will reveal the presence of rapidly growing strains, such asBacteroides or Clostridium, but reincubation for 5 to 7 days for primary plates is recommended, since some species, such as Bilophila, Desulfovibrio, and Porphyromonas, may not be detected with shorter incubation times and require at least 4 to 5 days for growth (84, 85, 91). For successful culture and susceptibility testing of anaerobes, a strictly anaerobic atmosphere needs to be maintained inside the chamber, jar, or bag. Chambers may fail to keep a proper gaseous condition in an especially busy laboratory and, therefore, repeated quality controls should be performed; e.g., with a simple method of growing an aerotolerant Clostridium perfringens strain with a metronidazole (5 μg) disk, an inhibition zone of >27 mm indicates acceptable anaerobiosis (297).

Increased awareness of the importance of anaerobic organisms as a cause of systemic infections may contribute to the increase of their isolation and detection in blood samples in clinical microbiology laboratories. For instance, to reliably detect anaerobic organisms, the BACTEC Lytic/10 Anaerobic/F culture medium (Becton Dickinson) has been shown to be a rapid and reliable method, improving the detection of low levels of anaerobic bacteria, such asPrevotella and Fusobacterium, in the sample (117). In a separate study, it was shown that blood culture sets comprising one aerobic bottle and one anaerobic bottle have higher pathogen yields than two sets of aerobic bottles (298). There is broad variation in anaerobic blood culture practices among hospitals, even in industrialized countries (172, 299). Chapter 5 of this Manual gives more information about blood culture systems.

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: After anaerobic incubation, the relative quantities of distinct colony types are recorded. Plates should be examined with a dissecting microscope to facilitate detection. Even after incubation for 7 days, certain species, such asDesulfovibrio and Dialister, grow as transparent colonies that are pinpoint in size and are easily overlooked in mixed cultures (74, 85, 277, 278). Figure 1 gives an example of a mixed anaerobic culture, in this particular case a sample from a pelvic abscess of a patient using an IUD for >10 years. The isolates should then be subcultured onto BA and, at this point, a rabbit laked blood agar plate (available from Kohjin-Bio Ltd., Japan) for the rapid demonstration of pigment production; an egg yolk agar plate for the demonstration of lipase, lecithinase, and proteolytic activities may also be inoculated. The primary plates are reincubated along with the purity and test plates.

figure.title: FIGURE 1 Typical cultivable microbiota associated with a pelvic abscess. The anaerobic Gram-negative species were identified as Prevotella corporis (brownish colonies), Porphyromonas asaccharolytica (black colonies), and Sneathia vaginalis (flat small colonies). Other species involved in this mixed infection are Gardnerella vaginalis (flat colonies) and Atopobium vaginae (pinpoint colonies). Incubation for 72 h in an anaerobic atmosphere on BA.

sect1.title: Presumptive Identification
sect1.para: Colony morphology of an isolate in pure culture can be useful for presumptive identification. For example,F. nucleatum can appear on the plate as speckled, iridescent, or bread crumb-like colonies, while B. wadsworthia has typical black-centered colonies on BBE (91). Colony morphology, together with the capability of erythrocyte agglutination, is among the features that can be used to separate the two F. necrophorum subspecies using phenotypic tests (300). The agglutination procedure, using human and chicken erythrocytes, is performed by a glass slide method, where agglutination is observed by mixing a drop of bacterial suspension and a drop of erythrocyte suspension on a microscope slide. F. necrophorum subsp. funduliforme (agglutination-negative) colonies are pulvinate (very convex or cushion-shaped), creamy, and glistening with entire margins, whereas F. necrophorum subsp. necrophorum (agglutination-positive) colonies are convex or umbonate, waxy, and dull with erose margins. Also, observation of hemolysis may be of diagnostic value; for instance, both F. necrophorum subspecies exhibit beta-hemolysis when grown on horse blood agar (300). Hemolytic properties on human blood may aid in separation of different Leptotrichia species (301). Production of pigment is another visible characteristic valuable in presumptive identification; the pigmented Gram-negative anaerobic rods are composed of saccharolytic and asaccharolytic species of the genera Prevotella and Porphyromonas and pigment-producing Alistipes species. In this context, it is notable that the statement “after 4 days incubation on laked rabbit blood agar, colonies appear black” in the original description of A. onderdonkii and A. shahii (9) is incorrect. Instead, the grade of pigmentation is light or moderately brown on rabbit laked blood agar and, under long-wavelength (365 nm) UV light, colonies appear black. Appearance of pigment requires fresh medium and expanded incubation (147). As a novel observation, a diffusible brown pigment on BBE can be useful in presumptive identification of Alistipes species (147). The pigmented Prevotella and Porphyromonas species vary greatly in the degree and rapidity of pigment production (2 to 21 days), which ranges from buff to tan to black (Fig. 2), depending primarily on the type of blood and the composition of the base medium used in the agar (91). Fluorescence under long-wavelength UV light can be helpful in presumptive identification; pigmented Prevotella and Porphyromonas colonies typically fluoresce red (Porphyromonas gingivalis is among the nonfluorescent species of human origin), F. nucleatum and F. necrophorum fluoresce yellow-green, and Desulfovibrio and Bilophila species, when tested with a drop of 2 N NaOH on a swab of cell paste, fluoresce red due to the presence of desulfoviridin pigment (91, 279, 300). Figure 3 gives an example of how fluorescence helps to distinguish colonies and differentiate some anaerobes.

figure.title: FIGURE 2 Pigmentation varies among phylogenetically close species. Top row: the Prevotella intermedia group organisms, (A) P. aurantiaca, (B) P. intermedia, (C) P. nigrescens, and (D) P. pallens. Bottom row: the Prevotella melaninogenica group organisms, (E) P. denticola, (F) P. jejuni, (G) P. loescheii, and (H) P. melaninogenica (courtesy of Mervi Gürsoy).

sect1.para: Microscopic determination of the morphology of Gram-stained bacterial cells can aid presumptive identification of the organisms present. Among fusiforms,F. nucleatum usually exhibits long, spindle-shaped cells with tapered ends, while F. necrophorum and F. mortiferum have highly pleomorphic cells, with or without swollen areas and large round bodies (6, 197, 300). Leptotrichia cells, which often stain Gram positive in fresh cultures, have been usually considered as long rods; however, this description fits only with L. buccalis, L. hofstadii, L. shahii, and L. trevisanii (301, 302). Dialister species are small coccobacilli, making their distinction from Gram-negative cocci difficult (74). Desulfovibrio piger typically stains bipolar (279). Wet slide preparation for microscopic examination reveals the motility of Gram-negative anaerobes: Selenomonas displays a characteristic tumbling motility, often moving side-to-side across the field; Fretibacterium fastidiosum is an important member of the highly motile fraction of the periodontitis-associated microbiota. Anaerobiospirillum cells are spiral with corkscrew-like motility. Desulfovibrio species, except for D. piger, appear as curved rods with rapid, progressive motility (85, 87, 303).

Inhibition of growth by bile or antibiotics is useful in identification of anaerobes. TheB. fragilis group, in particular, and most Bacteroides species are typically bile resistant (2, 91). Pigment-producing Alistipes can be readily distinguished from pigmented Porphyromonas and Prevotella species by the resistance to 20% bile (8, 304). Among fusobacteria, F. mortiferum, F. varium, and some strains of F. necrophorum grow in the presence of bile, whereas F. nucleatum does not. The profile of susceptibility to special-potency antimicrobial disks (a zone size of ≥10 mm is considered susceptible), containing vancomycin (5 μg), kanamycin (1,000 μg), and colistin (10 μg), is useful in presumptive identification of many Gram-negative anaerobic taxa (Table 2). Gram-negative anaerobic rods are typically resistant to vancomycin, with pigmented Porphyromonas species, Butyricimonas, and Sneathia vaginalis (formerly S. amnii) the only exceptions (9, 11, 12, 64, 91). Susceptibility to both kanamycin and colistin is characteristic of Fusobacterium and Leptotrichia/Sneathia species, Sutterella wadsworthensis, and Tannerella forsythia (74). Among motile Gram-negative organisms, Anaerobiospirillum is usually susceptible to colistin, unlike most Desulfovibrio and Selenomonas isolates.

figure.title: FIGURE 3 (A) Differentiation of colonies by fluorescence exemplified by a saliva sample (100 μl, 10–4 diluted) plated on Columbia blood agar and incubated under anaerobic atmosphere: Prevotella melaninogenica (colonies with reddish fluorescence), Prevotella nigrescens (red fluorescence in the center of the dark-pigmented colony), and Fusobacterium nucleatum (large colonies with greenish fluorescence). (B) Same sample under natural light. Images courtesy of Laura Wendt.

sect1.para: In addition to the characteristics listed above, there are some simple tests that are within the scope of most clinical laboratories. For example, a bile-resistant organism with typical darkening of the center of colonies on BBE can be easily recognized asBilophila wadsworthia by its strong catalase reaction with 10 to 15% H2O2 (84), and by combining positive indole and lipase reactions, a Fusobacterium-like organism can be tentatively identified as F. necrophorum (197). An indole- and lipase-positive short rod that forms black-pigmented colonies and fluoresces red can be identified as P. intermedia/P. nigrescens, while P. pallens resembles these indole-positive species but has lighter pigment and is lipase negative (91). Bilophila and Sutterella typically reduce nitrate. A characteristic smell may guide the identification; a foul smell produced by butyric acid and other metabolic products is typical for Fusobacterium species, while a strong sulfur smell is typical for the presence of Desulfovibrio species (85, 279).

sect1.title: Biochemical Testing
sect1.para: With a steadily increasing number of new species, biochemical testing and differentiation may soon lose its accuracy. In culture-based biochemical testing, the main techniques for classification of anaerobic organisms and distinction of individual species include sugar fermentation reactions, using prereduced, anaerobically sterilized (PRAS) carbohydrates or commercial test kits, and the determination of enzyme profiles with individual diagnostic tablets or preformed enzyme kits. In addition, the determination of major volatile fatty acid end products of glucose metabolism, as detected by gas-liquid chromatography (GLC), is a useful adjunct to biochemical and physiological tests (91), but together with analysis of the long-chain fatty acids found in bacterial cell walls it is beyond the scope of most clinical laboratories.

Commercially available test kits, such as the API 20A, API ZYM, and Rapid ID 32 A (bioMérieux, Marcy-l’Etoile, France), RapID ANA II (Remel, Lenexa, KS), BBL crystal identification (Becton Dickinson), and AN MicroPlate (Biolog Inc., Hayward, CA) systems, are used for testing preformed enzyme and carbohydrate fermentation profiles in clinical microbiology laboratories (305). Diagnostic tablets (e.g., from Rosco, Taastrup, Denmark, and Key Scientific, Stamford, TX) are also useful for determining individual enzyme reactions of anaerobic isolates. A heavy inoculum from 2- to 3-day-old cultures should be used for testing to obtain optimal reactions. When using different test systems, variation of test results is expected due to differences in the substrate specificities. These rapid, easy-to-use systems are best suited for fast-growing and biochemically reactive anaerobes, such as the B. fragilis group organisms, but even then it may not be possible to reliably identify the isolate to the species level. The VITEK 2 ANC card (bioMérieux) is an automated system for rapid identification of anaerobic (and coryneform, combined as ANC) bacteria from clinical specimens (306, 307). According to the results of a clinical trial performed in three large tertiary-care centers (307), the VITEK 2 ANC card allows the rapid and acceptable identification of the most common clinically important anaerobic bacteria within 6 h. Improvement is required for the identification of, e.g., members of the genera Fusobacterium and Prevotella (307, 308). Currently (April 2022), the system’s database for anaerobes includes only 82 organisms. The skillful and accurate reading of the Gram stain preparation considerably improves the percentage of correct identifications (306, 307).

The most commonly encountered bile-resistant organisms in clinical specimens belong to theB. fragilis group organisms. They grow as gray, circular, convex, and entire colonies on BA and, in addition, grow well on BBE, where they (except for B. vulgatus) blacken the agar by hydrolyzing esculin. Based on their resistance to special-potency antibiotic disks (vancomycin, kanamycin, and colistin) and a few rapid tests, such as the catalase, indole, esculin, and α-fucosidase tests, they can be initially reported as the B. fragilis group or organisms most closely related to this group (91). Testing with β-glucosidase can differentiate B. dorei from B. vulgatus, and a negative catalase reaction can identify B. xylanisolvens (309). The genus Parabacteroides includes the former B. distasonis and B. merdae (310), and B. splanchnicus has been moved to the genus Odoribacter (29). In addition, clinically relevant species include P. goldsteinii and P. gordonii (Table 4) (56, 168, 170, 311). All Parabacteroides species are negative for indole and α-fucosidase, except for the newly described P. chongii, thus distinguishing them from the B. fragilis group organisms. P. goldsteinii is phylogenetically and phenotypically very similar to P. merdae; however, P. goldsteinii is positive for α-glucosidase and β-glucosidase (Rosco), whereas P. merdae is not (168). Furthermore, its positive β-glucuronidase reaction separates it from P. distasonis. Unlike other Parabacteroides species, P. gordonii does not hydrolyze esculin and does not ferment trehalose (170). Most of the B. fragilis group and related organisms are highly fermentative. Table 4 presents the key characteristics for distinguishing the B. fragilis group organisms, including Parabacteroides and Odoribacter species.

In general, mostAlistipes species can be separated from Bacteroides by their pigment production; however, fresh rabbit laked blood agar and prolonged incubation are then required (8, 147). Nonpigmented exceptions are the type species of the genus, A. putredinis, and the recently validated A. ihumii. A. putredinis is bile sensitive and asaccharolytic (6). A. finegoldii, A. onderdonkii, and A. shahii strains grow well on solid media, where colonies appear beta-hemolytic, but not well in liquid media with or without supplements (8, 147). They are variably saccharolytic due to their poor growth in liquid media and are bile resistant and catalase negative. More characteristics about Alistipes species are summarized in Table 5 (8). Tannerella forsythia is a fastidious oral pathogen, and human strains require exogenous N-acetylmuramic acid for growth in pure cultures (21, 174). Key characteristics of T. forsythia are its sensitivity to bile and positive trypsin and esculin reactions. Notably, animal strains from bite wound infections are positive for catalase and indole (312). The new Tannerella species, T. serpentiformis, shares many biochemical reactions but is negative for esterase and N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase (22).

Porphyromonas species, except for P. catoniae, P. pasteri, and P. pogonae, produce pigment. The identification of the closely related and phenotypically similar P. asaccharolytica, P. endodontalis, and P. uenonis is difficult due to their slow pigment production and inactivity in biochemical testing. Testing with prereduced, anaerobically sterilized carbohydrates is not helpful in distinguishing these species, but glyoxylic acid and glycerol in the AN Microplate system (Biolog Inc.) enable their separation: P. asaccharolytica is positive for glyoxylic acid and P. uenonis is positive for glycerol (9). In addition, the differences in the degrees of pigmentation may be helpful, with P. uenonis having the most pigmentation and P. bennonis showing the least (9). A positive trypsin reaction is typical for P. gingivalis (91) and P. pogonae. Unlike most Porphyromonas species, P. bennonis, P. pasteri, P. somerae, and P. catoniae are indole negative, and—except for P. bennonis—also weakly saccharolytic (10–12, 15), which may lead to their misidentification as Prevotella species in clinical laboratories (10, 11). P. bennonis is a slow-growing organism with very slight pigmentation after extended incubation of at least 10 days and has a variable susceptibility to vancomycin (12). Unlike other Porphyromonas species, it produces major amounts of acetic and succinic acids in GLC, and some strains are catalase positive. Most Porphyromonas species of animal origin have been differentiated from the human strains by a positive catalase reaction (91). For P. pogonae, both animal and human isolates are described as catalase positive (16). Table 6 presents the key reactions for distinguishing Porphyromonas species.

A small number ofPrevotella species produce indole (Table 7) (34, 36, 91). Although most prominent Prevotella species are pigment producing, only half of them show a brownish color within the first few days, and most Prevotella species are nonpigmented. For example, P. colorans is weakly pigmented up to 5 days of incubation, but the color intensifies when further incubated (190). P. fusca, P. scopos, and some strains of P. histicola have a bull’s-eye appearance due to pigmentation of the colony center (32, 33). Noteworthy is that pigment production, as well its degree, on blood agar may take up to 14 days and vary from tan to brown to black depending on the species (for examples see Fig. 2). Colonies of P. jejuni are surrounded by a varying degree of hemolysis (41). Detection of lipase on egg yolk agar may be useful: P. intermedia, P. nigrescens, and many P. loescheii strains are positive (313). Besides the production of pigment and indole, Prevotella organisms are characterized by their capability of fermenting a variety of sugars. Prevotella species produce acetic and succinic acids as their major metabolic end products of glucose fermentation in GLC; however, P. marshii, unusually, also produces propionic acid (314). Notably, the separation of the majority of Prevotella species is not possible by phenotypic methods. Due to the high and still increasing number of Prevotella species described based on 16S rRNA gene or genome sequencing, their precise identification by biochemical tests reaches impracticality. However, Table 7 lists reactions that are valuable in the identification of Prevotella and related genera.

Fusobacteria can be presumptively identified by a limited number of simple laboratory tests, including cell morphology with Gram stain, growth in 20% bile, and indole production, but their definitive identification to the species level may require additional biochemical testing (Table 8). Using GLC for volatile fatty acid determination, detection of propionate produced from lactate and/or threonine has been used to separate differentFusobacterium species (91). F. nucleatum, appearing as white-yellowish (chartreuse, pronounced under UV light), speckled, or bread crumb-like colonies, is known for its wide heterogeneity. It includes four (to five) subspecies, F. nucleatum subsp. animalis, F. nucleatum subsp. vincentii (fusiforme), F. nucleatum subsp. nucleatum, and F. nucleatum subsp. polymorphum, but phenotypic tests are not able to identify the organism to the subspecies level. Also, F. periodonticum is indistinguishable from F. nucleatum by phenotypic methods. In the case of the increasingly clinically important F. necrophorum, there are two subspecies, F. necrophorum subsp. funduliforme, isolated mainly from human infections, and F. necrophorum subsp. necrophorum, usually from animal infections (197, 199, 300). Both subspecies are indole and lipase positive, but colony morphology and a few phenotypic tests, including erythrocyte agglutination, are able to distinguish them (300). A selective agar for F. necrophorum, containing nalidixin and vancomycin as well as defibrinated horse blood without heat treatment, which allows the direct detection of beta-hemolysis, was found nearly as reliable as real-time PCR in detecting the organism at medium and high concentrations in throat swab samples after 2-day incubation (315). An interesting possibility—with economic justification—is culturing throat swabs from adolescents for F. necrophorum, followed by antimicrobial treatment when indicated, to reduce preventable invasive complications (230). An indole-negative pleomorphic organism that grows on BBE may be presumptively identified as F. mortiferum (91). F. ulcerans closely resembles indole-negative F. varium strains but reduces nitrate.
