All fusobacteria produce major amounts of butyric acid as their metabolic end product (Table 2), and, in addition, F. naviforme, F. russii, and F. varium produce lactic acid, as detected in GLC (91).

AlthoughLeptotrichia and the more fastidious Sneathia species are anaerobic on first isolation, in subcultures some strains can grow aerobically in the presence of CO2 (241, 246). These organisms have been known as large fusiforms; however, their cell morphology varies among the species: L. buccalis, L. hofstadii, L. shahii, and L. trevisanii are long rods whereas L. wadei and L. goodfellowii (recently reclassified as Pseudoleptotrichia goodfellowii [61]) are relatively short rods, while S. vaginalis (formerly S. amnii or “L. amnionii”) has been seen as pleomorphic coccobacilli and fusiforms and S. sanguinegens as pleomorphic rods with some filaments (62, 254, 301, 302). Interestingly, the cells of S. vaginalis (formerly S. amnii) were described as variable-size rods up to over 10 μm; however, tandem electron microscopy revealed that the long rods were actually formed of chains of bacilli with rounded ends (64). Fresh cells may stain Gram positive (241, 246). Lactate production as the major end product of glucose fermentation is characteristic for Leptotrichia and Sneathia (Table 2). Sneathia species are extremely fastidious, and thus not much is generally known about their biochemical characteristics (62, 64, 250, 254). The genome sequence analysis of S. vaginalis (formerly S. amnii) revealed a small genome size that might explain its fastidious nature and its vancomycin susceptibility (64). Positive reactions by Rapid ID 32 A (bioMérieux) have been reported for β-glucuronidase, alkaline phosphatase, arginine arylaminidase activity, and raffinose fermentation (250, 254). Table 9 presents some characteristics helpful in the biochemical identification of Leptotrichia, Pseudoleptotrichia, and Sneathia organisms.

Within the phylumSynergistetes, Fretibacterium fastidiosum (65), Jonquetella anthropi (66), Pyramidobacter piscolens (67), and the newly described Rarimicrobium hominis (68, 69) are the human-derived species that have been cultured so far. They are extremely fastidious in nature, requiring incubation of 7 to 21 days, and thus are difficult to characterize. These Synergistetes organisms are asaccharolytic rods, with acetic acid (and R. hominis with acetic and propionic acids) as their major metabolic end products of glucose fermentation. F. fastidiosum forms very small, highly convex colonies on blood agar, but the colony morphology can vary (65). A coculture with other oral bacteria or a filtered cell sonicate of F. nucleatum subsp. nucleatum is needed for optimal growth. F. fastidiosum is motile, unlike J. anthropi and P. piscolens. J. anthropi is susceptible to bile and forms pinpoint colonies on blood agar, while the colonies of P. piscolens are somewhat bigger and highly convex to pyramidal and its culture has a specific fishy odor (66, 67). R. hominis has irregular rod-shaped cells and appears as punctiform colonies even after prolonged incubation, and the seafood odor is also typical (68). All species are unreactive to most biochemical tests. In the Rapid ID 32 A system (bioMérieux), F. fastidiosum and J. anthropi are positive for both glycine arylamidase and leucyl glycine arylamidase, while P. piscolens is highly positive for glycine arylamidase (65–67). Although the Cloacibacillus species C. evryensis and C. porcorum were recently isolated from human bacteremia cases (69), they are still largely uncharacterized, and conventional methods used in clinical microbiological laboratories are not able to identify these strictly anaerobic Gram-negative rods. The three human isolates were resistant to vancomycin and colistin but susceptible to kanamycin (68, 69).

Dialister species are coccobacilli that form tiny colonies on blood agar. They are asaccharolytic and grow poorly in liquid media; lack of reactivity in conventional biochemical tests hampers their identification. They are often confused with Veillonella because of their tiny cell size. There are a few enzymes in the Rapid ID 32 A system (bioMérieux) that may be useful in distinguishing three Dialister species: D. pneumosintes is positive for glycine arylamidase; D. micraerophilus for alanine, phenylalanine, serine, and tyrosine arylamidases and arginine dihydrolase; and D. succinatiphilus for alkaline phosphatase (23, 74). However, D. invisus and D. propionicifaciens are negative for all tests in this kit. The latter species produces propionate, which can be detected by GLC (74). Molecular methods, such as 16S rRNA gene sequencing, are often needed for the accurate detection of Dialister species in clinical specimens (74, 261).

Bilophila wadsworthia isolates are asaccharolytic, bile resistant, and strongly positive for catalase, and most strains are urease positive (84). This species also produces hydrogen sulfide, and its growth is stimulated by bile (oxgall) and pyruvate. This pattern, together with its typical colony characteristics on BBE, may result in its reliable identification.

Two humanSutterella species, S. wadsworthensis and S. parvirubra, and two human Parasutterella species, P. excrementihominis and P. secunda, are asaccharolytic and very unreactive organisms, of which only S. wadsworthensis has been isolated from infections so far. P. excrementihominis, P. secunda, and S. parvirubra are strictly anaerobic, have coccoid cells, and are negative for nitrate reduction (76, 82, 316), while S. wadsworthensis is a straight rod that is able to grow in microaerobic conditions and to reduce nitrate.

Of the motile Gram-negative anaerobic genera isolated from human specimens,Selenomonas and Anaerobiospirillum are saccharolytic, while Desulfovibrio and Phocaeicola are asaccharolytic. Flagellae of Selenomonas are arranged on the concave side of the cell, while those of the related genus Centipeda are around the cell (77). Anaerobiospirillum species have a corkscrew shape and a jerky motility. A. succiniciproducens is susceptible to colistin, and it ferments glucose, maltose, lactose, and sucrose. A. thomasii can be differentiated from A. succiniciproducens by carbohydrate fermentations and by α-glucosidase and β-galactosidase activities, the former being negative and the latter positive for both reactions (87). Desulfovibrio species are curved rods with a rapid, progressive motility (except the nonmotile D. piger) and are resistant to colistin and to 20% bile (except for the bile-sensitive D. desulfuricans) (279). A rather simple test scheme, including catalase, indole, nitrate, and urease, is able to separate the four Desulfovibrio species isolated from human clinical specimens (279). Unlike the others, Desulfovibrio species are positive for desulfoviridin, which can be detected by adding 2 N NaOH to cell paste on a swab and observing for red fluorescence under UV light (85, 279). Desulfomicrobium orale is a straight rod and is negative for desulfoviridin but, typically, both D. orale and Desulfovibrio species reduce sulfate to H2S by consuming hydrogen, a major end product of fermentation (86). Phocaeicola abscessus is a slow-growing coccobacillus with lophotrichous flagella arrangement (54).
Table 10 presents an identification scheme for motile Gram-negative anaerobic genera.

sect1.title: Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization–Time of Flight Mass Spectrometry
sect1.para: Bacterial identification by matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) has proven to be a promising method for the identification of anaerobic bacteria, including Gram-negative organisms (313, 317–321). Conserved proteins on a taxon level, such as ribosomal proteins, are used as identification targets. These characteristic peptides and small proteins (ranging mainly in m/z from 3 to 15 kDa) can be measured after laser desorption and ionization of whole cells, cell lysates, or crude bacterial extracts. Accurate identification depends on the unknown organism being present in the database. At present, two systems are available for the routine identification of aerobic and anaerobic bacteria: the IVD MALDI Biotyper (smart) system (Bruker Daltonik GmbH, Bremen, Germany), with the yearly updated MALDI Biotyper (MBT) software and compass library (in vitro diagnostic [IVD]; other versions address research [RUO] and industrial microbiology [GP]) and the VITEK MS IVD (bioMérieux), with a frequently updated IVD and a separate RUO (SARAMIS) database. More anaerobic species are included in the Biotyper (Bruker Daltonik) system database (latest version V6 with 9,234 total Main Spectral Profiles [MSPs]). The percentage of correct identifications of Gram-negative anaerobes at the species or genus level, compared to the phenotypic identification or 16S rRNA gene sequencing, depends on the active development of the databases of the different systems in the field of anaerobic bacteria (318–321). Different sample preparation methods may also influence the correct identification; however, no significant differences have been observed in the success of species identification among the tested strains of Bacteroides and Fusobacterium species, whether the direct smear or a full chemical extraction was used (322). In a study on 123 clinical Prevotella isolates, 60% were identified with direct spotting and 14% after a repeated procedure, whereas 26% needed ethanol-formic acid extraction until identified (313). Bacteroides strains resulted in species-level identification, whereas Fusobacterium strains were usually identified at the genus level, but problems encountered within the Fusobacterium genus may be resolved by adding well-characterized strains to the databases. During a 4-year study period in Spain, investigating 4,094 anaerobic strains (190 species and 50 genera) isolated from clinical samples, only 2.1% of the isolates could not be reliably identified by the Bruker system database (V6) and required sequencing for a final identification (323). Even phylogenetically closely related species within the genera Bacteroides and Prevotella, such as B. salyersiae and B. nordii (318) or P. intermedia and P. nigrescens (319, 320), can be correctly identified by MALDI-TOF MS. However, novel species may be misidentified as their phylogenetic relatives, e.g., P. aurantiaca as P. intermedia and P. jejuni as P. melaninogenica (313). Similar to some other aerobic and anaerobic species, peak shifts can be found and used for typing of the divisions I and II of B. fragilis (324, 325). As only isolates in division II harbor the cfiA gene that is responsible for the production of the carbapenemase, typing of B. fragilis by MALDI-TOF MS may have a direct influence for the selection of antibiotic treatment (326). Some recent progress in the field of MS-directed identification of anaerobes and carbapenemases is summarized elsewhere (327–331).

sect1.title: Genetic Identification Methods
sect1.para: Another method, which can reliably detect as-yet-unnamed taxa as well as identify known species, is 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis (332). For clinical purposes, a 500-bp sequence from the 5′ end of the gene is able to identify most, but not all, members of this group to the species level. Even more information per amplicon length can be derived by using V6-specific primers (292). These methods are being increasingly used for identification of anaerobic bacteria, because (partial) sequencing of the gene is faster and more accurate than biochemical testing and, notably, independent of the growth characteristics (125, 333). Sequencing of the rpoB gene has also proven its potential for bacterial identification (334). For instance, rpoB gene analysis has been successfully used for distinguishing two closely related Fusobacterium species, F. nucleatum and F. periodonticum, and for oral isolates versus isolates from intestinal biopsies (335).

Sequencing, as a routine method, may not be feasible for many clinical laboratories. The development of algorithms to screen for those isolates that can be adequately identified by conventional methods and to refer difficult-to-identify isolates for 16S rRNA gene sequencing has been proposed (125, 332). Also, commercial 16S rRNA gene sequence-based identification kits, containing reagents for DNA extraction and amplification, are available. However, they require instruments including a thermal cycler, an automated gene sequencer, and software for interpretation, and the data needed to assess their value in identifying Gram-negative anaerobes are not available. Although sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene is a useful method for identification of fastidious anaerobic organisms, providing a much faster turnaround time than conventional methods, molecular analysis should complement but not replace culturing in the clinical setting. As a new and promising approach, next-generation sequencing (NGS) of metabolic pathway genes can identify essential nutrients and help to optimize culture for otherwise overlooked species (336). In the field of routine clinical diagnostics, the application of NGS is currently limited to typing for epidemiological purposes, even though the implementation of NGS for microbial community analysis may yield clinically important information. This lack of NGS implementation is due to many different factors, including issues relating to standardization, reproducibility, and clinical importance of results (337). The future challenge for clinical laboratories will be the translation of vast amounts of accrued NGS microbial data into convenient algorithm testing schemes so that clinically relevant information can be reported to physicians in a format that is understood and actionable (338). 16S rRNA-targeted sequencing in conjunction with culture could be useful for identifying bacteria in normally sterile body fluids, especially when patients have been pretreated with antibiotics and when anaerobic infection is suspected (339).

Genetic signatures, applied as DNA probes in colony-blot hybridization assays, are useful for enriching and isolating new species from mixed cultures. On the other hand, phenotypic characteristics, obtained by culture and biochemical testing, assist in correlating the sequence-based data, which can be sometimes difficult to interpret, for example, due to incomplete sequences stored in the reference database. More importantly, culture is necessary for antibiotic susceptibility testing of isolates from clinical specimens. Thus, genetic and culture-based methods are complementary in all instances.

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: Antimicrobial resistance among Gram-negative anaerobes continues to rise (340–344). This means that important anaerobic pathogens are not per se susceptible to piperacillin-tazobactam, carbapenems, or metronidazole but have to be identified and tested for susceptibility. Although susceptibility to antimicrobials can vary considerably among species within the same genus, most clinical laboratories neither perform the accurate species-level identification of the isolated organism nor test the susceptibilities of anaerobic isolates (305).

Table 11, based on current literature, summarizes antimicrobial resistance rates worldwide of the clinically most relevant Gram-negative anaerobic taxa. This summary is based on four conditions, as follows. (i)Bacteroides species are among the most antibiotic-resistant anaerobes and are addressed with priority here. The Bacteroides fragilis group members (Bacteroides other than B. fragilis) are more likely to be resistant to certain antibiotics (e.g., β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combinations) than B. fragilis. B. fragilis susceptibility data are reported separately, as it is the most important (and type) species of the genus Bacteroides, and to enable comparison of data over decades. Parabacteroides data are presented separately. (ii) Prevotella and Fusobacterium data are included, but data of many other genera are excluded as too limited. (iii) Studies not explicitly reporting percentage of resistance, or at least percentage of nonsusceptibility, were not included here, with the exception of eravacycline studies, acknowledging its important contribution to the future antimicrobial agent armamentarium (345, 346). Studies providing only MIC data leave too much room for interpretation. In the case of eravacycline, however, we carefully interpreted the MIC data despite lacking CLSI/FDA or EUCAST guidelines. (iv) We had to make a compromise between reporting most recent data (isolation year of strains presented here is usually 2010 or later) and coverage of the global situation. A few older data from less frequently monitored regions of the world or from underrepresented antibiotics were thus kept from the last edition of the Manual of Clinical Microbiology (347).

According to surveys conducted in North America, Europe (Belgium, Denmark, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Poland, Turkey, Slovenia, Spain), and many other countries (Argentina, Hong Kong, China, India, South Korea, Kuwait, Pakistan, Taiwan),B. fragilis, the B. fragilis group, and Parabacteroides species are among the most resistant anaerobes to various antimicrobial agents (340–343, 347–352). One of the largest studies by Forbes et al. (343), addressing 485 B. fragilis, 473 non-B.fragilis Bacteroides, 60 Parabacteroides, 244 Prevotella, and 101 Fusobacterum strains, is used as a core reference for the completely updated Table 11. In a recent study that included 421 extraintestinal B. fragilis isolates in Kuwait, the authors reported almost 50% of strains enterotoxigenic (fragilysin, bft positive) and resistance rates against amoxicillin-clavulanic acid of 32%, clindamycin of 62% (reaching 67.6% in bft-positive strains), cefoxitin of 26%, imipenem of 11%, meropenem of 17%, metronidazole of 4%, and tigecycline of as high as 14% (340). In a 2020 study from Japan, 50 B. fragilis blood isolates were tested; the resistance rates were ampicillin-sulbactam 30%, piperacillin-tazobactam 6%, clindamycin 32%, cefmetazole 16%, imipenem 4%, meropenem or doripenem 10%, metronidazole 0%, and tigecycline 14% (352). In a 2020 European-wide study by Sóki et al., in total 202 Bacteroides/Parabacteroides strains (of which 11.9% were B. fragilis) were isolated from fecal specimens of healthy donors (n = 42, from five European countries) who did not have an enteric disease and had not received any antibiotics for at least 3 months prior to testing (350). The percentage values of isolates resistant to ampicillin, amoxicillin/clavulanate, cefoxitin, imipenem, clindamycin, moxifloxacin, metronidazole, tetracycline, tigecycline, and chloramphenicol were 96.6%, 4.5%, 14.9%, 2.0%, 47.3%, 11.4%, 0%, 66.2%, 1.5%, and 0%, respectively. For comparison, in a study from Denmark (359 consecutive fecal B. fragilis group isolates from patients receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics), the authors found higher resistances to carbapenems (5% in case of meropenem) and to β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combinations (11% in case of piperacillin-tazobactam), respectively. Furthermore, three metronidazole-resistant Bacteroides spp. (B. fragilis, B. ovatus/xylanisolvens, and P. distasonis) were isolated (353). Among all 267 (2016–2019) isolates tested in a 2020 study from Greece, the lowest rates of resistance (<5%) were detected to carbapenems, metronidazole, chloramphenicol, and tigecycline (342). Resistance to piperacillin-tazobactam was observed in 5.4%, 24.6%, and 3.3% of B. fragilis, B. fragilis group, and Fusobacterium spp. isolates, respectively. Cefoxitin resistance was low for Prevotella spp. (3.2%) and Fusobacterium spp. (3.3%). Results for Bacteroides and Parabacteroides species from Poland again confirm that the problem of resistance is mainly related to strains belonging to non-B. fragilis Bacteroides (341). In the analyzed periods (2007–2012 compared to 2013–2017), the authors found an increase of clindamycin- (35.21% vs. 53.33%), amoxicillin/clavulanic acid- (2.83% vs. 8.15%), and imipenem- (1.41% vs. 3.7%) resistant Bacteroides strains and observed a constant high (approximately 50%) clindamycin resistance among P. distasonis strains. Testing 508 clinical isolates of 19 Prevotella species from different parts of Europe, Kuwait, and Turkey according to EUCAST and CLSI/FDA guidelines, Ulger et al. (351) found that Prevotella species were susceptible to piperacillin/tazobactam, imipenem, meropenem, tigecycline, and metronidazole. Furthermore, ampicillin/sulbactam and cefoxitin also showed good activity, whereas ampicillin, clindamycin, tetracycline, and moxifloxacin were less active with 51.2%, 33.7%, 36.8%, and 18.3% of isolates, respectively, nonsusceptible. A total of 49 (9.6%) isolates were resistant to three or more antimicrobials. Prevotella bivia was the most prevalent species (n = 118) and accounted for most of the multidrug-resistant isolates (15).

There are many new studies describing resistance genes and various mechanisms of resistance among Gram-negative anaerobic pathogens. The diversity of such genes inBacteroides and Parabacteroides strains was recently described in depth by Rong et al. (354). A total of 71 phenotypically resistant Bacteroides spp. from human clinical specimens were screened for the most relevant antibiotic resistance genes. For background, the cfiA gene in B. fragilis encodes a powerful Ambler class B metallo-β-lactamase that can hydrolyze nearly all β-lactam antibiotics and was indeed the most frequently found β-lactam antibiotic resistance gene in this study, which is in contrast to other studies where cepA had a higher prevalence. Many resistance mechanisms against clindamycin and the group of MLSKO (macrolide-lincosamide-streptogramin, ketolide, and oxazolidinone) antibiotics have been found, with important rRNA methylase genes such as ermB, but especially ermF and ermG, among Bacteroides spp. Moxifloxacin resistance is associated with the presence of genes coding for efflux pumps such as bexA, a member of the multidrug and toxic compound extrusion class (MATE) genes, although it is assumed that point mutations in the gyrA gene play the most important role. Due to its intensive use, increasing resistance to tetracycline and acquisition of tet genes (with tetQ dominating) has been observed. Regarding metronidazole resistance, 11 isoforms of the nim genes encoding a nitroreductase are known (nimA through K), with nimA being the most prevalent gene in Bacteroides. In overall summary of this German study, tetQ was the most frequently detected gene, followed by cfiA, ermF, cfxA, ermG, cepA, nim, and bexA (354). This study reveals that we still do not know all the mechanisms relevant for expression of phenotypic resistance. Some other recently published articles addressing resistance mechanisms and genes are recommended for further reading (352, 355–358).

A publication by the ESCMID Study Group on Anaerobic Infection (ESGAI) is on the way, evaluating cases where the empiric therapy failed due to resistance of anaerobic pathogens and only a second-line treatment allowed the patients to be cured. Other cases of clinical failures could be linked to the lack of timely detection of resistance (including heteroresistance) (359, 360) of anaerobes, despite the fact that simple agar diffusion methods (disc diffusion or Etest methodology) are suitable in most cases to detect vitally important resistances (361).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Knowledge about the resident microbiota and awareness of the role of anaerobic bacteria in disease permit the clinician to anticipate the likely infecting species at different body sites. Training for anaerobic techniques, in general, and introduction of advanced methods for the detection and precise identification of anaerobic organisms are urgently needed in clinical microbiology laboratories. The major issues are (i) increasing frequencies of anaerobic bacteremia and septicemia (114, 115, 121), (ii) increasing numbers of patients with fusobacterial infections (209, 213), as well as (iii) increasing resistance rates of anaerobes to various antimicrobials (341, 342, 344, 349, 350, 352, 355, 356). In cases of inaccurate microbiology and inappropriate choices of antimicrobial agents in treating an anaerobic infection, mortality rates and other treatment failures increase significantly (115, 200, 204, 361). Collection of clinical specimens should avoid the mucosal microbiota, and proper transport media and times should be used for keeping the anaerobes alive. Factors such as foul-smelling discharge, proximity of infection to mucosal surfaces, abscess formation, and necrotic tissue indicate the presence of anaerobes in the specimen. A definitive identification of an anaerobic isolate, at least to the genus level, should be obtained for all isolates from normally sterile body sites, including blood, spinal fluid, and organs or body cavities; when the patient is gravely ill and not responding to treatment; and when prolonged treatment is necessary. It would be desirable for reference laboratories to periodically provide information on local susceptibility patterns of anaerobic species within the clinically important taxa. However, not only appropriate antimicrobial therapy but also proper surgery, such as the drainage of abscesses and excision of necrotic tissue, is important in resolving anaerobic infections. It is notable that chronic infectious lesions, in particular, include consortia of bacteria organized in biofilms. This leads to reduced diffusion of antimicrobials and increased MICs.

The most important, and often difficult, task in the reporting of results of the isolation of Gram-negative anaerobes is determination of whether the organism is involved in the infectious process or is merely a bystander originating from the patient’s commensal microbiota. All isolations from normally sterile sites should be regarded as significant. A secondary challenge is that these organisms are often found in polymicrobial infections, with a number of different species present and often as a biofilm. Obtaining pure cultures for susceptibility testing can therefore be time-consuming and the resulting susceptibility profiles may be conflicting, making the recommendation of appropriate antimicrobial therapy difficult. Fortunately, such infections typically respond well to empirical treatment, as partial disruption of the bacterial consortium responsible is sufficient to allow the body’s defenses to deal with the infection. However, with continuous emergence of antimicrobial resistance, the value of empirically selected therapy may soon be lost.
